segments.text: This is Ron Shorn interviewing Fred Franklin.
Fred, would you say something for our mic?
How about Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Saturn, and Uranus?
This is Ron Shorn on April 22, 1993, at the Center for Astrophysics in Cambridge, Massachusetts.
And I'm interviewing Fred Franklin.
Fred, what's your full name?
Fred Aldrich Franklin.
And when and where were you born?
I was born in Worcester, Massachusetts on July 24, 1932.
How did you first get interested in astronomy?
Long pause.
Long pause.
Well, I had a grandfather who was interested in astronomy.
I never knew him, but he left a lot of books behind.
I had a chance to browse through those.
We had a fairly active natural history society that urged people or children to come and visit, and I guess I went there, and it was quite an active astronomical group.
There was a very good astronomy club there, and I had several friends who became keen on astronomy.
This is at the age of 8, 9, and 10, and in fact, three of us made careers of it.
We were together, too.
Or Ed Olson.
now at the University of Illinois, and Werner Neuper, who was at Goddard, Greenville.
So these things play on each other.
Ed was a tiny bit older and very good with making telescopes.
So we had quite a number of possibilities of developing interest.
And so it began in that way.
And I must say, the local astronomy club was very nice.
The older people in that were very helpful toward the
the younger generation, and they incorporated us into their programs and went observing, looking at eclipses and having talks and so on, visiting other observatories.
So that was a nice introduction.
Where did you go to undergraduate school?
I was very keen to come to Harvard, and so I did.
What year did you graduate?
And what was your major?
Astronomy.
Astronomy major.
And your minor?
I don't know that we had any minors.
I guess I was a minor, but I'm not sure I had one beyond that.
So when you entered, you knew you wanted to be an astronomer.
Ron, it's funny.
I decided that with rare wisdom, I guess, that I was not going to follow the practical dictates of my family, but at least for a while I was going to do what I felt was fun to do and wanted to do.
I didn't really think of making astronomy a career, but I didn't think also that it was appropriate to come to college and plan
exactly what you wanted to do, let's say in a commercial or business-like sense, I decided just to study what was interesting and fun.
And always expecting it probably would stop the next day or the next year.
There'd be a knock on the door and I'd be sent out to the salt mines or something, but I really wanted to study the things that I liked.
And it was a
more a case of good fortune in terms of timing that allowed me to make a career of things.
What was the good fortune in timing?
I think as I was in graduate school and getting out of graduate school.
And that was for Harvard?
That was Harvard, too.
That was as the Sputniks were in orbit, and suddenly astronomy was a very active field with much more money infused into it.
NASA was founded, and suddenly many small or medium-sized colleges and universities were starting departments.
So that there was, as opposed to present time, there was an opening market for people who would teach or do research in astronomy.
It was a very fortunate and rare, I think, business.
When did you get your PhD?
And what was your thesis topic?
I worked on Saturn's rings under the aegis of Fred Whipple as a formal advisor.
What about the rings?
Stability or their composition or physical structure?
Several areas, really.
There's been a lot of rather low quality photometry of the rings, measuring the opposition effect in various colors.
So I set about doing that to try to get really good photometry and to separate the brightness contributions of rings A and B.
So part of it was, first, the obtaining the photometry over a six month period.
and then analyzing that.

And then once that had been done, looking into the stability questions, too, whether the rings were a stable phenomenon, a stable system or not, to redo some of the Maxwell work, the classic Adams Prize essays of the last century.
So it was a two-pronged effort, really, but basically designed to try to get a fairly good comprehensive picture at that time of the dynamics and structure of Saturn's rings.
When did you decide to go into things planetary rather than galaxies or cosmology or stars?
It's a very, very good question, and you'll get a, because it's a good question, a rather poor or fragmentary answer, but I'll do the best I can.
And perhaps there's no overwhelming, compelling reason, but a little bits of motivations here and there.
I think when I was a graduate student at Harvard, it was sort of a transition time, in a way.
It was the Shapley era had ended, and Donald Menzel was the director.
It was perhaps not because it was a transition and a number of things were happening.
It was not perhaps the very finest hour of the observatory.
Bach, who was, of course, very keen on attracting students, left when I was a graduate student.
And in general, it was an unsettled era.
It seemed maybe a semi, well, let's say unconsciously to me that the person whom I was attracted to for his science and for his interest and his thoughtfulness was Fred Whipple.
Dr. Menzel was developing his solar project, was traveling a lot.
There was nothing very attractive to me there.
Bach was very keen on attracting students, but he was a very emotional man.
And somehow, it didn't somehow quite gel with me.
I liked him very much.
I admired him very much.
But there was something that kept me away from galactic astronomy.
Perhaps because he was thinking of leaving, also
He was keenest, of course, at that time on radio astronomy, and I felt electronically very ungifted.
I was fascinated by theoretical work.
Max Crook was here, who was a marvelous person, but hard to work with because he was hard to find.
Somehow, it was a case of being interested in theory and the feeling that Fred Whipple was
wise and good, helpful man.
And another reason was that one of the people who came to work with him, Alan Cook, was at that time unmarried and often here, and we talked a lot.
And Alan is a very bright fellow.

He's an interesting person in many ways, but he was certainly always available to talk to, and so a number of the work, a certain amount of the work we did was, I did on the range, was done in collaboration with him.
So it was a case of having good people to talk to and a certain amount of stability, I think.
There was no conscious decision on my part to study planetary astronomy.
After you got your PhD, where did you go?
It was interesting.
I rather wanted to stay here, but there was a good feeling that it was wise for students not to spend too much time in one place.
And I was offered a teaching position at the University of Massachusetts.

At that time, and still to this day, University of Massachusetts and some of the surrounding institutions like Smith and Amherst and Hampshire and Mount Holyoke have formed now a five-college department.
At that time, it was a smaller number of people, but I was invited to come and teach at the University of Massachusetts and join that, I guess it was at that time, four-college department.
I knew several of the people there.
It seemed like a rather nice thing to do.
And as I remember, I was finishing the thesis with about three minutes to spare.
And so I didn't want to take the time to find applications for positions.
And this one, in some sense, came looking for me.
So I was delighted to accept it.
An old friend of mine, Ed Olson, whom I mentioned earlier, was there at the time, and that was a very nice lead-in.
So I went out there and had a very pleasant year.
I have to say that maybe two-thirds of the way through it, Fred Whipple called and asked if I wanted to return on the Smithsonian staff.
And I was only too happy to accept, because a year there was fine, teaching I
could do, and I guess adequately.
But it wasn't something that I felt was my great calling.
I was rather keen to come back to work.
To spend a year or so doing something new, say recovering from graduate training, was fine.
But I was very glad to come back.
And so you came back here in what, 60?
I came back here in the summer of 1963.
What research did you do when you first came back here?
keen on working more on the structure of Saturn's rings, on the gaseous envelope around the rings.
I was also interested in doing more photometry.
In fact, Fred Whipple had a project he wanted me to look into.
And perhaps that was one reason why he lured me back.
There had been some work on the Smithsonian side on rather approximate photometry on the Earthshine.
And he wanted someone to work on that and see if he could
make a little more sense of the Earth's albedo as determined by measuring the Earth's shine.
And so I was able to do that.
It was not a tremendously exciting project, but it was good fun to do that.
I think I was keen on working principally on the Saturn system, on looking into the satellites, particularly the rings, the interrelation between the rings and the satellites.
And I have to say that
In my graduate training, I never took any courses in celestial mechanics.
And I began to realize that if you're going to work in areas in the solar system, you should know at least a little bit.
So I felt that I should pick up some knowledge in that area, too.
What have you been doing since then?
Give us a synopsis.
Well, I have been keen on the rings for a long while.
But I must say, again, my interests have turned a little bit away from that to problems related to dynamics, to some of the planetary satellites.
Another friend and I colleague have worked for some time on the mutual phenomena, that is, the eclipses and occultations of the Galilean satellites, the long-term hope being that we can
unravel the tidal evolution of Io's orbit.
We're on the threshold, I think, of being able to do that, or at least set limits on it now.
But we did a number of measurements of the eclipses, timings of the eclipses and occultations to get highly accurate positions.
I'm also fascinated by chaos, by motions of chaotic objects, and whether chaos and instability go hand in hand.
our chaotic orbits per force unstable.
That's been my keen activity for the last number of years.
Do you think that people who worked on the planets were considered second-class astronomers back when you started in this field?
I have to say I can't give any specific examples, but my feeling is yes.
Certainly in the interactions here, and I can name names if you like, but please do.
I don't think people would object to this.
Everyone who's been at Harvard will know, back in my day, that Bach was a marvelous man and very keen on talking with students and bringing them along.
But he had very strong emotional responses, and I have to say, as we all do, I guess, prejudices as well.
And certainly from him, as he was the first real astronomer whom I got to know here, there was the feeling that galactic or possibly extragalactic astronomy was the essence of things.
And the other things were solar system was a backwater, which really didn't count for very much.
And if one wanted to do anything or be marketable, to put it crassly, you certainly didn't pay much attention to the solar system.
I'm not sure he put things in so many words, but the feeling was definitely there.
Of course, he was riding the wave of radio astronomy, which was developing fast.
And he had a very strong point that that was going to be a major field.
And one might be well advised to become involved with it.
But there was more than that.
There was sly remarks that people who dealt with the solar system really were leftovers.
not probably first-rate people in general, and that one really wasn't advancing the cause of astronomy if you lingered too long in the solar system.
I think that's a fair statement.
I can't, again, give you any specific examples, and I don't mean to saddle him as the only person who made these remarks.
But I do associate them with him, and I think not unfairly.
Do you think that these days, planetary astronomers have second class status?
Again, I can't give any strong examples.
But I generally feel that's the case.
I think probably with some of the grand successes of the last decade or decade and a half, that feeling has been, in some sense, lessened.
But I think that's probably true, that still planetary people are generally felt to be somewhat less than in the forefront.
I sort of worry sometimes, at the center for astrophysics, we will lose this planetary group.
I think under the present regime, that's unlikely.
But I think had Erwin Shapiro not been the director, we very well might have disappeared.
And maybe there's a good reason for that.
I have to say, in general, I think planetary people are not regarded as the most significant in the astronomical community.
Where did you get your funding for your work the last 30 years?
The last few years?
The last 30.
Thanks, Ron.
When I began here, the Smithsonian really had a mission, formally, to study what was in the solar system.
The initial wording was that they studied material between the surface of the sun and the surface of the earth, which was very restrictive.
Fred Whipple quickly got that expanded.
But still, with Whipple and with this background, there was still definitely a feeling that our main concentration was in the solar system.
In any event, since that was my interest, funding
Smithsonian at that time was fairly easy to come by.
I remember getting a couple grants to do assorted things.
I guess the Earthshine was a grant that we had, and some other things, too.
Some satellite astrometry that Cora and I had a grant for for a while.
But at least at that time, funding was fairly easy.
And since the Smithsonian's mission was mainly in the solar system, and there wasn't a great deal else being done in the solar system,
Money came rather freely, I think, from SI itself, or SAO itself.
And one, although was encouraged to get grants, and I guess I did from time to time, there wasn't a great deal of need to do that.
In fact, one grant, I think from NASA, almost sought us out to do some of the work for them.
It's a very different picture from now.
What was your first NASA grant?
And when was it?
I think it was do this Earthshine work.
It was a smallish grant, and it was to do some fairly comprehensive extensive photometry on the Earth, Sean, and that was probably back in the mid-60s.
It lasted only for a couple of years, and I think it was a specific request from them to write the grant because they wanted this work done, and so we did it and then carried it through.
What do you think NASA's impact has been, or NASA's money, has been on the field of planetary astronomy?
I think it's been striking and valuable, and I'd say enormous.
Just to go on from where we were before, Alan Cook and I put in to join the Voyager mission.
Since we'd worked on Saturn's rings together, we joined it together.

it turned out my interests were turning slightly at the time, and it turned out for a number of reasons to be appropriate for him to do most of the consulting and be the formal member of the Voyager team.
But I followed along and checked a lot with him, and occasionally consulted and went out to JPL.
But I just make the obvious remark that without NASA there would have been no Voyager, and without Voyager there would have been
a totally different view of the solar system.
Both for Smithsonian funding and for NASA funding, how have those funding sources treated you?
Have they been nitpicking?
Have they interfered?
Or have they basically let you do what you said you were going to do?
Ron, I've been very fortunate.
essentially on the SAO staff, I guess you might say on the tenured staff, you can do pretty much what I like.

It's true if I want a fancy computer, if I want to travel somewhere, I have to get funding, but I have been very fortunate of having a position which more resembles an academic position, so I can do what I like without having to go out and get funding to maintain myself.
So I only need it for
occasional special items.
It's not a very good answer, but you see my position is a little bit different, because I haven't had to worry about this question directly.
I think you included this earlier, but what are you working on right now?
Right now, two projects, the tidal evolution of the Galilean satellites, and perhaps even more actively, chaos in the asteroid belt and the origin of Kirkwood Gaps.
What, in your opinion, is the most important
work you've done.
I'm enormously excited about chaotic motion in the solar system.
I hope it's important.
A little group of us of three here have been keen on trying to establish the relation between measurements of chaos and eventual instability.
And we think we see a fairly successful statistical relation between the two.
It has to be checked further, but it seems to me significant both in a scientific and almost philosophical sense.
I find it very exciting, perhaps because I'm on top of it now, but I really like this and I'm quite excited by it.
It's an empirical relation to date, and one should try to establish more theoretical understanding, but I really
I have to say what I'm doing just now on chaos and instability seems to me most interesting and possibly most enduring.
Well, you also answered my next question, which is what was the most fun?
Most wonderful fun, yes.
Did you ever blunder or run into a stone wall or get entangled in some swampy mess that you said, oh, I wish I had never thought of this and never gone into it?
I suppose so.
This isn't a very good example, but let me give it anyway.
Both by myself and with Alan Cook, we did work.
And BepiColombo.
I mustn't forget BepiColombo.
We did do a number of studies of Saturn's rings.
And toward the end, we were trying to understand better the structure of the rings in terms of the resonant interactions with the satellites.
That obviously was very difficult.
And it was with a certain sense of relief and delight

I heard from Bill Ward that Peter Goldreich and Scott Tremaine were working on the project and would clean it up because, well, everybody knows their unique power, but I felt that I was unable to go sensibly any further, and the subject obviously needed more insight and more physical treatment, and it was nice that good people had gotten into the job and were going to do that.
That's sort of an answer to your question, I think.
I pretty much shot my bolt, I think, and was glad to turn it over to the major leagues.
Just say the question once again, Ron, and I'll think again.
Have you ever made any real blunders or gotten into a field where you weren't getting enough
enough wasn't coming and you were hitting a dead end, or it didn't seem like the results were going to be worth the effort you put into it?
Well, along the first part of your question, yes, there was one paper that never got published that was delightful that it never did.
I think it was something that Alan Cook and I wrote, and this is back pre-Jim Elliott days.
We had a fairly
ornate and obviously fallacious reasoning why there weren't going to be any rings around the Planet Uranus.
Saved by the bell.
Saved by the bell.
And we wrote a paper, which we sent off, and the referee with great wisdom and foresight said, this really isn't very persuasive.
I don't think this should be published.
This was maybe three or four years before Jim Elliot discovered the ring.

It was based somehow, I think, on the feeling that because the inner satellites of Saturn were so prevalent, they seemed to define the boundaries of the ring, and there were no inner satellites around Uranus, not in the right positions anyway, probably any early Uranian ring would dissipate.
Anyway, we gave the paper a terrible name called On the Absence of a Ring Around Uranus, which someone said sounded like a soap commercial.
It's quite right.
Anyway, the paper never got published, and you can imagine with what great relief I view that today.
Where do you publish most, or where have you published in the past, and has that changed over the years?
I guess most of the planetary work we've sent to Icarus.
We had a little trouble with some of the referees on Icarus, and lately have been sending things more frequently to the Astronomical Journal.
The work on chaos, I guess, has now had two or three papers there.
But this is only, what shall I say, a glitch, or at least a temporary change.
But Eckeres and the AJ have been the major repositories.
Do you get the impression that the AFJ doesn't want work such as yours?
Oh, no.
No.
Well, golly, this was some years ago.
I'm at the urging of BepiColombo, basically.
We went and reanalyzed some of the stratoscope observations of the shape of Uranus.
This is, again, back before Voyager.
Just before, though.
Because of a number of reasons.
Anyway, we went back with new equipment to reanalyze the data of Danielson.
and found that, in fact, we could improve upon it substantially and derive an ellipticity or geometrical ablateness for Uranus.
And I can't quite know the reason.
This was a paper of Charlie Avis at the JPL, and Bethany Colombo, Erwin Shapiro, and I.
We sent it to the APJ, I guess because that's where Danielson's first work.
on Project Stratoscope had appeared, and it was published without great difficulty.
So I don't suppose it's a journal that was first thought of in terms of planetary work, but this one seemed to be appropriate for there, and it was accepted.
Do you think having a journal such as Icarus devoted just to planetary astronomy is a good thing?
Well, one good thing, of course, is that it hasn't
and all the other major astronomical journals do, and they're heavy page charges.
So certainly, Icarus, I think, is a good journal from that technical reason.
I agree, though, beyond that, that I think its focus is so strictly planetary, but broad planetary, both dynamics, optometry, its spectroscopy.
I think it's a very, very good thing to have it.
I'm very much an avid reader, although not a describer of Icarus.
When we were graduate students, there was just an American Astronomical Society, period.
Now there are a lot of sub-societies, and the Division for Planetary Sciences is one of them.
Do you think that's a good deal or a bad deal?
I think it's inevitable.
So in that sense, it's good.
It's just too diffuse now to have one society being concerned with the entire topic.
That, in a sense, is regrettable, but it seems to me inevitable.
in a sense, the result of a very healthy growth in all areas.
We know, of course, now that simultaneous sessions occur at all Astronomical Society meetings.
And I still like to go occasionally and just see some people and listen to some areas that aren't my own.
That the AES meetings, I mean.
But I think it's inevitable and necessary that this field be more focused.
I'm unaware, anyway, of any great
loss of generality or failure to keep up with things because of this separation.
Not a very helpful answer, not a very unusual answer, but it seems to me hard to think of the lies.
Well, that brings up the next question.
You yourself, there's a lot of astronomers around CFA.
Do you talk to the stellar and galactic and cosmological types, and do they ever talk to you besides saying hello when you pass in the hall?
Yes.
Yes, I think I can answer that very definitely.
Well, I'll just give you an example.
I've been serving for several years now on several committees, reviewing applications for postdoctoral fellowships and predoctoral fellowships.
And it's a wonderful thing, because it gives me a chance to read over applications,
talk with colleagues about subjects that I am somewhat familiar with, but not very familiar with.
And I find that to be a demanding but rewarding exercise.
So I can say, I guess, that in a group as large as this, perhaps these stimuli occur out of necessity.
But they're, I find, very valuable.
If it weren't for a little bit of pushing, I think I would probably become more narrow.

But I think, again, the place as large as this with many, many journal clubs and talks, colloquia, and lunchtime gatherings, the ability to stay fairly general, at least in a somewhat shallow sense, is there.
And that's very helpful and very nice.
What are the biggest differences you see between planetary astronomy and this
when you started in the early 60s and now?
Well, certainly, the activity in the field is totally different.
Back in the early 60s, there were very few people.
You knew virtually everyone, or could know everyone.
I think you felt, perhaps, at that time, you were united by the small numbers game
you were a small cause in yourself, and you wanted to keep the lights burning.
We've grown to such a degree that that feeling of being an endangered species, perhaps, is not quite so prevalent.
I think, Ron, I have to say, too, that as I get older, I get somehow the feeling that
since there isn't a huge amount of time left, perhaps I want to concentrate and do the things I want to do and I'm interested in.
So I don't try to get so involved or so active in causes, promoting things, or worried about things that aren't sort of in my first line of interest.
And at present, I'm keenest on the science itself, and so I'm not very active in
committees or meetings or pushing various agendas.
I like to do the science itself and have been rather selfish in that regard.
What do you think the status of planetary astronomy is now?
Growing, shrinking, or hanging in there?
Well, I think it certainly grew so and produced a certain amount, perhaps, of
well, perhaps lived in an unrealistic world.
I guess it is probably shrinking.
I do not believe it will ever go back or shrink to the level it was, say, after World War II.
I think there's too much... What shall I say?
There are too many interesting problems that are meanable to...
observations or techniques or studies that are sufficiently rewarding and basic that the subject will certainly continue.
And perhaps that was the problem back in the 30s and 40s, that there was just no tremendously advancing technique to solve many of the problems.
Now we do have those, but maybe they'll have to be measured out
in smaller doses, but I don't believe the field will disappear or be set back simply because the techniques to advance it are so powerful and the people are here to use them.
I guess I look in terms of a settling back, some projects perhaps being put aside, but the questions are basic and the techniques are sufficiently advanced that the subject will not
diminish greatly, I feel.
Do you think planetary astronomers have done a good job of selling what they do to the public?
In other words, do you think they presented their case well and actually affected the public thinking to any extent?
I guess I would say they have done rather well.
Again, I'm sorry, I don't think of any particular probing or exciting answer to that.
If you'll forgive me for just giving you such a blank and unqualified answer, I would be rather impressed by what they've done.
And I think the public relations have been really quite strikingly good.
Do you think this idea of selling planetary astronomy as a practical science, for example, diverting killer asteroids,
keeping the ozone in our upper atmosphere, stopping Earth from turning into Venus.
Do you think that emphasis to get funding at the expense of other problems is good or bad, or the best that can be done, perhaps?
My feeling is that if you don't argue honestly, you always regret it eventually, or someone will regret it eventually.
And I think that Killer Asteroids is not an honest sell.
Ozone, I suspect, to take your example, clearly is.
I would only say that I think you have to make an honest, a brutally honest approach to the subject.
And you will always regret it if you do not.
So I would be skeptical about some of the selling techniques.
Do you think that the failure to find life on Mars
had an effect on funding for planetary astronomy in general?
Oh, I suspect it did.
Somehow a more positive in terms of life result would have accelerated our interest.
Maybe we should have made a stronger point that the changes in the Martian obliquity leading possibly to periods of greater
of unleashing various internal water supplies still left the question open.
That's a possibility.
But I'm sure the detection of life would mean a great infusion of money.
Do you think the obliquity,
changes in the Martian obliquity may have a tremendous climactic effect.
Oh, yes.
When they first got those pictures showing stream beds, they said, well, it might be some fluidized thing.
And I just said, hell, it's water.
Why not?
